ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Command-line NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Ok I see your point. Perhaps it would be interesting if the NEAT core could be used from languages and platforms other than those already supported though NEAT

Ok I see your point. Perhaps it would be interesting if the NEAT core could
be used from languages and platforms other than those already supported
though NEAT ports (for example Smalltalk) without having to endure a new
NEAT port. I was wondering if NEAT could work in a client-server scheme with
the NEAT "engine" being the server and the client managing the experiments.
So far a command-line NEAT seems close to this and sounds good to me ;-)

I was asking if a client-server approach would be possible because as ken
pointed out there may be some complications.

Best Regards.

GV

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "John Arrowwood" <jarrowwx@...>
To: <neat@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, May 30, 2004 7:36 PM
Subject: Re: [neat] Command-line NEAT


> >From: German Viscuso <netquake@...>
> >
> >So perhaps it would be better to have NEAT acting as a TCP server, define
a
> >communication protocol and then connect with your client of choice (from
> >any
> >platform). Would it be possible/desirable ?
> >
>
> Depends on what you mean.  Yes, I could make some complicated application
> for managing connections and stuff.  But why?  A simple CGI script is far
> easier.  And just as effective.  I would still be able to have a client of
> choice.  But the communication protocol then is already defined...http.
And
> then I can leverage existing http communication libraries.
>
> The reason for the command-line version of NEAT is specifically to support
> that mode of operation.  A CGI script only lives for the duration of the
> request.  So, state of the experiment will have to be maintained on disk.
> That's easy enough.  And once it's ready, just hand it to NEAT to do the
> evolutionary part.  Clean, simple, effective. :)
>
>
>
>
